												Aaah this mess and what a mess it is.Back when The Banner Saga: Factions launched there was so much talk. Talk about ripping off the kickstarter backers (which they weren't ripped off they just never bothered to read), talk about the lawsuit for use of the word 'saga', talk about how the game was so perfectly balanced that it risked becoming stale.Now no one talks about The Banner Saga: Factions anymore.Looks like that last one came true.First of all this is a mini-game, a subgame if you will. The point of this game is solely to PvP so do not confuse it with the main product and likewise this review is for this game not the main game itself.TBS:F is like a game of chess...With only 4 pieces. But wait, each of those pieces come in 3(4) flavours so their is variety!Except not really. Confused? We gotta go deeper Leo!You have your typical 3 classes, you know Tank, damage dealer, how does it go again? shield smasher? Yeah thats it. Whats a healer?Now without sounding like an instruction manual every unit has 2 bars, a health bar and an armor bar. armor reduces damage but the lowest amount you can do is 1hp. Be warned however that losing your armor is a big deal and a low armor or armorless unit will be cut down in short order! This makes games very methodical. Do you snipe hits for 1 damage each trying to score an early kill, or do you whittle down armor and then deal devastating damage to quickly mop up and win? Afterall their are no healers so every match is a war of attrition!It works out really well and I can't do it justice with words alone, it is a simple idea that could have gone really badly but here it is balanced perfectly.Of course not all things are created equally in any video game and this one is no different so what sounds like an awesome and rivetting gameplay experience ends as a battle of patience as a losing player with 1 archer can still run away and then pick your remaining units off and trust me, they will. So every team has archers because being dumb doesn't pay off on the battlefield and most matches become mirror matches. Remember when I compared this game to chess? Imagine introducing a new piece into a game of chess. Imagine the sheer balance upset and new tactics that would bring to the table?! This game suffers that exact same issue because the balance is so fine, it is too fine and very easy to upset that balance.So what happened?It stagnated, what did you expect? A competitive game needs a lot to keep the crowds coming back. Look at DOTA, new champions every month is it? Streetfighter, new iterations just about every 2 years. This game? Not a damn thing since release.The music is fine as are the sound effects and honestly who even gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥ The music has to be great for people to sit up and take notice and here it is just above average. But the art, this game is graphically a piece of art. Playing this game is like visiting an art gallery it just looks so good!But you play a game to be entertained (usually) and this game is fleeting fun. Their is fun to be had don't get me wrong but when you decide to shake it up a bit and really get into the game you will realize their isn't much more to it to explore, what you see is what you get. So I can't recommend this game.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

												So you put together a team of viking and giant warriors and fight short tactical turnbased fights and tournaments to get renown, wich is used to buy more space for warriors or upgrade your warriors. You get matched against players with the same combined level of fighters, resulting in very even matches.The combat system is identical to the banner saga, with  the only exception of some small changes to the abilities of some units.Though I strongly recommend the game, there are some issues that you should know before playing.First of all it is a player vs player only game. There is no training mode or single player, if you want that you have to buy The banner Saga (strongly recommended as well).The second major issue is that the game seems kind of forgotten by the developers, there are memory leak issues that cause lag, and updates are close to nonexistent. The third issue is that most player quit due to the first two, or the fact that the gameplay changes very little over time, resulting in very few players online at any moment. This of course can cause painfully long periods of waiting for a match. This is also to some extent caused by the matching system, in wich you may be unable to battle anyone at all if you don't have enough warriors to put together teams of different levels (ironically happens predominantly to new players).With those things out of the way, this is really fun and challenging game for you tactics fans. The turn system is different from many other games and is of extreme tactical importance, and to me the number of classes and restrictions are enough for a large umber of tactics and combos. Adressing the issues: The first becomes a non-issue after like four fights. The community is great and everyone are excited for new players and will help you get started. The second issue is bad, but in theory if more people play it the devs should work more to upgrade it. It will also likely get a boost after the release of newly announced TBS2. The third issue is the hard one. I personally don't think its boring, just as I dont think chess is boring, even if chess hasnt got any upgrades or new skins for decades =). And remember that many quit because there are too few players already. what kind of logic is that? But I won't judge anyone who played the game for a year and a half, waiting for someone to fix  the lag and crash issues, and stopped playing when nothing happened.Try it out though. it's Free! and fun!

												If you like the combat and art style of The Banner Saga, then you will find joy in Factions. Matches consist of ranked or unranked "friendlies" where you compete against 1 other person using a set-up of the classes found in the original game - Varl and Human. Each match earns you Renown (should you win) and the ability to level up your team, much like was done in the game. I've seen some reviews commenting on the lack of people on the server, or matches hard to come by, and I write this review mostly to say that I haven't had any difficulty finding a match. In fact, I often see a lot of the higher level (by +2 levels) matches popping up looking for an opponent.The beauty of the team system is you can level some favourites but also have a team of lower level so you can try out different play styles without waiting longer than a couple minutes for an opponent. I imagine a lot of this relies on the time of day you are looking, but the community is quite active and with TBS2 shortly being released, I see even more people coming into Factions.

												Normally I don't like Free-2-Play-Games and the likes because they often feel like the most commercial games of all. However, I guess as long as it's not "pay to win" or "pay or else you'll have to grind for a thousand years" it's ok.I'm glad I checked this game out. I was intrigued by the art design and still am.I have only had 7 matches or so, so this is not a "complete" review, but thought I'd let you guys know this seems to be worth checking out (being free2play).In the beginning I had the feeling the mechanics were rather slim and every match would be pretty much the same, but I quickly realized that I knew only half of the strategic possibilities (and maybe tomorrow I'll say I knew only a quarter ;) ). It doesn't take you more than an hour to get through the little tutorial, watch the two further tutorial videos (click on the banner in the upper right of the town screen to get there) and look at the special abilities of your warriors in the proving halls. Then you pretty much know all you need; the rest you'll learn on the battle field and when upgrading to other warrior types with different abilities.The game has an atmospheric presentation and sound, is rather "quiet" but the tension in the matches can get your blood boiling.For now, the game is in a rather early state (so a full review wouldn't even be fair). Everything seems to work (except for battling friends for now) but sometimes you cannot get into the game because of server load or maintenance. Also the game feels a little sluggish and laggy at times, but that's not much of a problem because of the turn-based nature of the game.The in-game purchases don't seem to be necessary to enjoy the game (otherwise I would immediately stop playing it). Other than other colors for your warriors' clothes you can buy "renown" which is kinda like the currency in this game. You need it to upgrade your warriors and expanding your barracks. But you also earn renown for playing matches (even more when winning them) and it doesn't take forever for you to earn enough to upgrade your team from time to time. And since matches are put together via match-making, you won't have to fight an utterly overpowered team.So if you're really impatient, you can spend money (and I'm sure there will be plenty people who will), but you'll have just as much a good gaming experience without; so that's a fair system in my book.If you like chess-like games and/or nordic flair, try this game - it's not like it costs ya ;)See y'all on the battlefield (when friend matches are back on) :]

Posted: September 28, 2014
												The Banner Saga: Factions focuses on what really matters in a turn-based tactics game: the combat. Factions largely abandons the virtual dice rolls that define so many other strategy games in favor of basic math skills. Its clever two-stat system creates battles where the most skillful player wins, and when I pull off a move several turns in the making it’s rewarding in a way unlike comparative strategy games. Even if it stumbles in a few places, like the stingy way it doles out its in-game currency, tactics-minded players looking for something different should definitely check this out.The graphics is wonderful and the gameplay is very nice and fluid with deep battle and leveling system.What does bother me a bit is the fact that, altough you can earn money (which is called renown in this game) only by playing the game and unlock everything, it is a lot faster and easier to simply buy renown for real money, but that's very expensive for a F2P game (20 Renown = 1$, one battle lasts 30-40 minutes and can bring you a max of 12 renown, usually much less). This is a small problem, but it's not nearly enough to push me away from this great game.Altough you can "speed up" the process of unlocking areas, the game is definitely not pay2win (the only things you can buy are cosmetic items like different colored clothes or shinier weapons that do the same ammount of damage like normal ones).I really would pay for better cosmetic items, too, because I want more of this art. Inspired by the artist Eyvind Earle, the 2D art style of Factions manages to be striking without pushing my computer to its technical limits. It oozes style, with backgrounds that feel straight out of a Disney movie – if Disney made movies about bloodthirsty Vikings, that is. The strikingly well-done animations help seal it, making every ax blow, collapsing body, and movement a pleasure to watch.Good game, you should try it :)8/10

Posted: January 13, 2015
												The Banner Saga: Factions is easy to pickup, but offers incredibly deep gameplay. The real strategy comes in deciding on the composition of your team, and whether you are going to play defensively or offensively, focus on ranged or melee, have one or two powerful units or spread the ranks of your team evenly.I've played games that are outright brawls, and games that have been about cautious manuevering trying to outflank the other team. I would recommend giving it a fair try over a number of days as durng my first few hours I almost quit because the combat seemed too chaotic and I didn't appreciate the nuances.I really like the variety of classes, and love that some of the classes I initially regarded as weak have become my favourites. In fact I would say there are no weak classes and any unit can be good if you use it appropriately.This game is not in any way pay to win; each side builds a team of equal level based on character rank, so battles are evenly matched. So for instance a rank 6 team could be 1+1+1+1+1+1 or 0+0+1+1+2+2 etc. The payment options just allow you to build that team faster (or even instantly with enough purchased renown), so that does not give any advantage within a skirmish. I thoroughly recommend this to anyone who likes turn based tactical battles where skill is the overriding factor.

												Note:  As of this review, I've not played the single player version, The Banner Saga.This game is a very simple turn-based brawler.  In terms of pure mechanics, I'd say it plays like a stripped down X-COM: EU/EW, minus perma-death.  Or like viking flavored chess.  Of course, both of these examples are simplifications.I really enjoy the balance of the gameplay.  Even though it's pure PVP, I've never felt cheated, which IMO is unusual for a competitive multiplayer game.  There's only a limited stock of different units, part of why the game is so balanced.On the other hand, limited unit type means limited unit variation, which is unfortunate.  I've come to understand that besides not including enemy faction units (the dredge) from the single player, there is at least one more viking unit missing.Additionally, you earn Renown (your currency and XP) at a slow rate, clearly to induce you to go to the shop and spend real money.  However, paying doesn't grant access to anything that anyone else can except for skins and extra renown.  While I've spent a shameful amount of time on this game, I have a proportionately substantial team to show for it and I haven't paid a dime.  Unlike other F2Ps where I wondered "Well what was the point?" when I finally logged off. It's free.  It's balanced and fun.  It's rewarding and beautiful to look at.  I fully recommend giving it a try.

												I never thought I'd play a "Free 2 Play" multiplayer game in my life, heck, I even made a personal rule against it. Needless to say, The Banner Saga: Factions has become an exception to that rule. An excellent turn-based tactical battle game, with some wonderful 2D animation, Factions finds a comfortable place between being a Tactics Ogre/FFTactics/Fire Emblem style and something much closer to Chess. The primary reason the game skews closer to the timeless tactical classic is in it's turn order/initiative system, which keeps the game remarkably fair even when one player is ahead of another. However, some of the core elements you'd draw from other tactical RPGs (or just RPGs with turn based combat) such as special attacks are present, so it really is a hybrid. As someone mentioned in chat recently, this is sort of like the holotable game R2D2 plays with Chewbacca, except with Vikings. Now, you're not going to find much depth here beyond playing matches of this "Viking Holotable Chess" against other players. That's literally all there is. On top of that, the competition is mighty fierce, and the players who have stuck around are going to destroy you ably until you learn to form a solid strategy and build a team around it. But all that said, if you like testing your tactical mind for briefer snatches of time rather than dropping several hours into a single player outing, then this should certainly have you playing. Plus, it's "free" (all of the buyable items are either cosmetic or boosts to unlock things faster, but unlocks do not give an edge, so it's fine balance wise), so there's little reason not to try it.

												The pvp portion of this game is terrific.  I've never played anything like this game before.  The artwork and sounds are fantastic.  What's lacking is the community population, which is miniscule.  And also the lack of additions to this stand alone game which could benefit mightily from the introduction of new races, classes, levels of combat etc.With the community being so small it can be difficult for a newer player to advance and not get discouraged because there is some learning that needs to take place and understanding of sound tactics.  Also more advanced players will have more advanced units the longer you wait in the queue there can be some lopsided matches that are drawn.Main Pro's to the game are the utterly classic and beautfiul energy that was put into the game and setting.  It feels very immersive by itself.  You can also use numerous different compositions competitively.  There are numerous different styles that can compete from agressive surge forward teams that hard-charge, to sit back and play tank defense shield break and counter puncher style, and utilize also trap layers and debuff archer builds.  The game is neat, adult and children friendly.  A game like this either appeals to you very much for its core style that you enjoy, or you might not get it or dislike the lack of updates.  While there are similarities between the board and chess.  They aren't remotely similar.  You can arrange your units pre-battle like stratego, but also left/right and up/down.  You can put your group in a knot on the front lines to crash your enemy on turn 1 or spread them out on the back of the map so you have distance and can get your bearings if you want to play more cautiously.  A very nice feature to this game is that you can constantly modify, at no cost, the point distribution in 5-6 categories for each unit type between battles.  You can experiment each battle to find what works best and/or not to your liking.This game is very underrated and doesn't deserve all thumbs down. You can experiment each battle to find what works best and/or not to your liking.This game is very underrated and doesn't deserve all thumbs down.  If this game had updates at least every 3-6 months it would have a much larger community and would keep people coming back.I'm very appreciative of the developers introducing this game for free.  I've since purchased the main storyline game which is fantastic and plan on purchasing Banner Saga 2 once it releases this Winter.
